body.name: Gail's Family: Icehome, Book 4
body.description: I've had a full life: wife, mom, divorcee . . . and then alien property. All of that's changing now that I'm on the ice planet. Here, I'm free again, and I've found love once more. Vaza's older and a widower, but he knows how to make a woman smile both in the furs and out of them.Everyone around me has a baby in their arms or in their belly, though, and it's hard to be the only one without. I love nothing more than being a mama . . . and when I hear there's an orphan at the Icehome camp, I want to adopt him. Vaza and I have so much love to give, but will an alien baby love us back?Contains mature themes. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This is a book that has the fears and joys of motherhood wrapped into one. It is short, but full of so much feeling. I found myself tearing up and then laughing and doing it over and over. It truly embraced all the feelings and worries of motherhood and I wish I could read it for the first time again. Great job Ruby!

reviews.reviewText: While I liked Gail and Vaza’s love story, I really just read this as a mother awaiting Ghal and Z’rhern’s connection. At the end, I was smiling and wanted more story, but it was the right place to end it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Five stars--with a caveat
reviews.reviewText: I like Ruby Dixon. I love the big blue alien boys, and her Drakoni nearly as much. That is why I'm giving this book a 5-star review after my fourth pass through the IPB and Icehome series. However, the caveat: this book deals with the topics of not only the loss of a child, but of adoption. I feel a warning is needed for adoption survivors in particular.(And if you don't know what an adoption survivor is, then this warning won't help you.)The loss of Gail's teenage son (about twelve years? prior, and certainly well before her abduction and consequent enslavement) is touched upon, but is not the central theme. It is mentioned as an old loss, an important loss--but a loss that Gail has survived. This may be a problem for readers who are still trying to cope with a similar loss of their own but it is not explored in painful detail.However, the adoption theme is what I feel a reader needs to know about in advance--and that because these stories ARE HEAs (happily ever afters) many of the sensitive real life subjects that appear in the series overall DO get sugar coated at various points. It wouldn't be much of an enjoyable fantasy world if they weren't, amirite?But as an adoption survivor, I feel this particular story needs the caveat that this may be the one book of the series that you want to skip. Not because the infant in question is an orphan. Not because he was neglected or abused while being "fostered" (because he was not--rather, far from it). Not because he was placed with unsuitable or wrongly-motivated adoptive parents (because in most ways, Gail and Vasa are seemingly perfect for this new role).But because the difficult, painful process of integrating/melding completely unrelated persons into a solid family unit is suddenly resolved in a slightly disturbing manner: Gail, who hasn't nursed a child in at least twenty-five years and is now menopausal, decides to give the fussy alien baby her breast to comfort him. And after a trip to the Healer, she's also suddenly able to fully lactate again--and the adoptive infant that did not accept her AT ALL is suddenly transformed into an adoring four-armed bundle of joy simply because he's now nursing. Nursing a female of a completely different species, mind--as if all the problems with dietary intolerances he was having are solved by trans-species breast milk.Look, I get it that this IS a novella. It IS a HEA fantasy series. But this subject (the "adoption is a hell of a lot harder than this" subject) is WAY too big for the casual treatment it received in this book. And if it cannot be revisited at a future point in an honest manner, then I feel this series was better off without it being introduced at all.Other books have had heroines with far less than ideal childhood experiences, so I know awareness is there--but the hard truth is that it isn't merely the "foster care system" that presents a danger to children--or to adoptive parents. Adoption is simply far too important and complicated of a subject to be brushed up against so casually--and I will never be in favor of perpetuating the "if the adoption got approved, then everything must be fine" myth.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Adorable and Sweet. A nice slice into the Icehome.
reviews.reviewText: Gail’s Family is a novella taking place after Willa’s Beast and before Angie’s Gladiator.The series needs to be read in order.It’s a cute read. It’s not like the previous books in that we get a full romance and resonates.Gail is over 50 who will not resonate and Vaza is an older alien. Gail and Vaza are clearly already in an adorably loving and stable relationship, something that has developed in the background of the other books. Both have found pleasure and a relationship that works, but both miss not having children of their own. They get a chance in this story to adopt.Z’rhen is adorable and somewhat cranky. I enjoyed both Gail and Vaza’s POV. Their relationship is nice and they make a family together.This was nice slice into the life of the Icehome series. If you enjoy sexy aliens then I recommend picking up Dixon novel.Rated: 3.5 Stars

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Hooray for Silver Team!
reviews.reviewText: Having been adopted by a couple in their late fifties, I can totally relate to this book. Gail has had some tragedies in her life, losing her only son, divorce, waking up a slave! How much can one woman take!! After several years of slavery, finding herself on an Ice Planet and the object of one man's interest has to have been baffling. Every woman wants to be genuinely desired and treasured and that's what Vaza gives her. Knowing that resonance isn't possible, this couple is delighted at the opportunity to be parents to an orphan.I have enjoyed all of the Ice Barbarian series, and am now reading Icehome. Thank you Ruby for your incredible mind.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Gail has the opportunity to be a mom once more after the Islanders arrive ashore after the volcano destroys their home. She and her mate leave the first colony and travel via golden dragon to the beach where the orphaned baby awaits. She loves him immediately but he's hungry, and she has no milk for him until the healer helps her. A new family is born!
A Short but Sweet story is the Ice Planet Barbarians / Ice Home series.
A estória foi muito boa, e do jeito que eu sonhava. Ela não tem que rossanar para ter um filho e um marido apaixonado e dedicado. Realmente uma adorável estória.
Short and sweet but boy did i love every darn page of this book. Can't wait to read Angie's story next.
Gail and Vaza are such a sweet couple, full of respect and thoughtfulness. An ideal background for a lovely fourarmed baby. Made me enjoy the story very much. I highly recommend this book.

reviews.reviewText: It's so nice to have an older couple 's story I'm glad you wrote it the way you did. We oldies are by our child bearing years, but it doesn't mean we're by the romance and maternal feeling. I really enjoyed Gail and Vaza's storyline, and I hope others will as well
